Objective: To encourage students to generate questions and reflections about the problem of making the remote-controlled car respond quickly and reliably, and to explore their thinking as a group
Set Up the Question Board:
1)Before the lesson begins, set up the board in the classroom where students can write down their questions or thoughts.
2) Introduce the Question: How can we make the remote control car respond quickly and reliably to commands sent from the mobile app, even when the car is far away? 3) Provide Sticky Notes and Instructions. 4) Group Discussion: Divide students into groups and give them time to discuss with each other then let them stick their answers on the board

Lesson Plan
1. Engage
 Teacher Role:
o Activate Prior Knowledge: The teacher should help students connect the project to their existing knowledge and experiences. This can be done by:
 Asking students to brainstorm ideas about how to control a car remotely  Discussing the different components used in the project and their functions  Relating the project to other technologies that students are familiar with, such as video games or remote-controlled toys.
o Use engaging strategies (e.g., showing visuals, asking questions) to spark curiosity. o Provide support during discussions and encourage diverse viewpoints.  Expected From Students: o Active Participation in Brainstorming: Students should actively contribute ideas about how to control a car remotely. This includes:
 Offering suggestions, even if they seem unconventional.  Building upon each other's ideas.  Respectfully considering different viewpoints.  Examples: "Maybe we could use a remote control?", "What about a phone app?", "Could we use signals like radio waves?" o Connecting to Prior Knowledge: Students should make connections between the project and their existing knowledge of technology  Parts of the books included.
 Introduction: o The "Real-World Application" Hook
 The Hook: Show a short (10 second) video clip of a real-world application of remote- controlled technology. Example:

 A drone delivering a package. https://youtube.com/shorts/KbYCNYaHphM?si=C2UxZDTAOilyKReg
 The Preview: Briefly explain that these technologies rely on similar principles to what they will be learning.  The Question: Ask: "What are the advantages of being able to control something remotely, without physically being there?"  Connecting to the Lesson: Explain that they will be designing and building a small-scale remote-controlled car using Bluetooth, just like some of these real-world examples. o Show and Tell & Picture Walk: Bring out the actual components of the robotic car:  Arduino Uno  (2)Motors  L298N Motor Driver  Battery  Bluetooth Module
Show a simple picture of a basic circuit diagram showing how the components connect.  (Picture Walk): Display larger, clearer images or diagrams of each component. Briefly explain the function of each one in simple terms, relating it back to the idea of controlling the car remotely. For example, "The Bluetooth module receives signals from your phone, telling the Arduino what to do."
 Reflection: Purpose of Reflection: Encourages critical thinking and helps students connect story themes to lesson objectives.
2. Think
 Questions How can we make the remote control car respond qquickly and reliably to commands sent from the mobile app, even when the car is far away?  Strategy: o Scaffold Strategy: Ask scaffolded questions to lead students to a deeper understanding.
Begin with Simple Recall Questions:
 "What components do we use in the car to make it move?" (This helps students recall basic elements like motors, motor drivers, and controllers involved in the car’s movement.)  "What do you think Bluetooth is used for in this system?" (This question encourages students to recall how Bluetooth facilitates communication between the car and the mobile phone.) Progress to More Analytical Questions:  "Why do you think the car needs to respond quickly to commands from the mobile app?" (This question helps students think about the importance of responsiveness in controlling the car, especially in tasks like navigation or avoiding obstacles.)

3. Explore
 Teacher Role: Guiding the Exploration:
o Provide clear instructions: Explain the task: "Now, we'll start connecting the components and learning about how to control motor speed using PWM." o Demonstrate safety practices: Emphasize safety rules regarding electrical components, especially when working with batteries.

o Facilitate connections: Help students connect the motors, motor driver, and battery according to the circuit diagram. o Play the prepared video on PWM in Arduino. https://youtu.be/7OYLakRyjTc?si=sTPXokQCRRnFqO2U o Ask guiding questions: "What do you think will happen if we change the PWM values in the Arduino code?" "How can we use PWM to control the speed of the motors?" "What might happen if the PWM value is too high or too low?" o Encourage experimentation: Encourage students to try different PWM values and observe the motor's behavior. Monitoring and Support:
o Circulate around the classroom: Observe student work and provide individual assistance as needed. o Encourage collaboration: Foster a collaborative learning environment where students can help each other.
 Expected From Students: o Correctly wired circuit with motor, motor driver, and power. o Notes from the PWM video summarizing the key concepts. o Understand of how PWM works and how it affects motor speed.  Parts of the books included.
4. Explain
 Teacher Role: Provide Direct Instruction:
Introduce the Key Components: The teacher will introduce and explain the function of each component of the robotic car: Arduino Uno, motors, L298N motor driver, Bluetooth module, and the battery. o Arduino Uno: A microcontroller that acts as the brain of the car, controlling inputs (e.g., Bluetooth signals) and outputs (e.g., motor movements). o Motors: The motors allow the car to move by turning the wheels. They are controlled through the L298N motor driver. o L298N Motor Driver: This component is responsible for controlling the direction and speed of the motors based on signals from the Arduino. o Bluetooth Module: This allows the car to communicate wirelessly with a mobile device. o Battery: Powers the car’s electronics and motors. Explain How They Work Together: The teacher will guide students through the flow of information and power: The mobile app sends commands to the Bluetooth module. The Bluetooth module transmits the signal to the Arduino. The Arduino processes the signal and sends appropriate commands to the motor driver. The motor driver controls the motors, which in turn moves the car.
Ask students to explain the process in their own words, prompting them with questions like: "How does the mobile app send commands to the car?" "What role does the Arduino play in the communication process?" "How do the motors actually move the car based on the signals they receive?"  Parts of the books included. https://youtu.be/7OYLakRyjTc?si=sTPXokQCRRnFqO2U

 Activity - Do It:  Materials Needed 2 motors Arduino Bread board Motor driver Jumpers Battery Bluetooth module
 Step-by-Step Instructions o Connection Connection  Motor Driver Pinout • IN1: Control input for Motor 1 (Pin 2 on Arduino) • IN2: Control input for Motor 1 (Pin 3 on Arduino) • IN3: Control input for Motor 2 (Pin 4 on Arduino) • IN4: Control input for Motor 2 (Pin 5 on Arduino) • OUT1: Motor 1 connection (connect to one terminal of the first motor) • OUT2: Motor 1 connection (connect to the other terminal of the first motor) • OUT3: Motor 2 connection (connect to one terminal of the second motor) • OUT4: Motor 2 connection (connect to the other terminal of the second motor)  Bluetooth Module to Arduino • VCC: 5V (from Arduino) • GND: Ground (from Arduino) • TX: Bluetooth module transmit pin (connect to Arduino RX) • RX: Bluetooth module receive pin (connect to Arduino TX)  Connect the 5V and GND of the arduino to + and – of the bread board, so any need for a connection to the 5V or the GND of the Arduino we connect it to the + and – of the bread board o Circuit
 Expected From Students: Listen Actively: Pay attention to the teacher's explanation of the components and how they work together in the robotic car.
Understand and Describe the Process: Be able to explain how each component (Arduino, motors, motor driver, Bluetooth module, and battery) functions and how they interact to make the car work.
Collaborate with Peers: Discuss with classmates to check understanding and share ideas about how the system works.
Take Notes: Record important information about the components and their roles, which will help in building and understanding the robotic car.
5. Elaborate
 Teacher Role:
o Facilitate hands-on exploration by guiding students in assembling the robotic car. o Encourage critical thinking and problem-solving as students test and modify the car. o Support group work by answering questions and helping students troubleshoot. o Introduce challenges or extensions to deepen learning (e.g., modifying code or testing the car's range).  Expected From Students: o Be able to connect the car with the mobile application o Actively engage in building, testing, and modifying the car. o Collaborate with peers to solve problems and troubleshoot. o Apply knowledge to identify and fix issues in the system.  Parts of the books included.
